text:
Sonia sat on the bed next to him, her eyes locked on his face. Her heart raced and then sank. It was unbearable. He turned to her, his face ghostly pale. His lips moved, struggling to say something. A wave of fear gripped Sonia.

“What’s wrong?” she asked, inching away.

“Nothing, Sonia, don’t be scared… It’s all nonsense. Seriously, it is,” he mumbled, sounding delirious. “Why did I come here to put you through this?” he suddenly questioned, looking at her. “I keep asking myself that.”

He might have pondered that a while ago, but now he spoke without clarity, shaking all over.

“Oh, you’re in so much pain!” she said, her voice filled with worry as she stared at him.

“It’s all nonsense… Listen, Sonia.” He managed a weak smile for a moment. “Remember what I wanted to tell you yesterday?”

Sonia waited, anxious.

“I said I might be saying goodbye forever, but if I came back today, I’d tell you who… who killed Lizaveta.”

She started to tremble.

“Well, here I am to tell you.”

“Did you really mean it yesterday?” she whispered, struggling to speak. “How do you know?” she asked quickly, as if she was afraid of the answer.

**PAGE SUMMARY:** Raskolnikov struggles with his guilt and the impact of his actions on Sonia, revealing his inner turmoil and the need for confession.
